INTRODUCTION

In response to the requirements of Federal EPA, this Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Cliffside Steam Station (CSS) located in Cliffside, NC.  CSS is owned and operated by Duke Energy.

PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION

CSS has installed a new anhydrous ammonia system as a component supporting selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions.  Ammonia vapor (in the presence of the SCR catalyst) reduces NOx compounds to elemental nitrogen and water to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.

The anhydrous ammonia system is comprised of two storage tanks, each with a capacity of 45,000 gallons, along with feed pumps and vaporizing equipment.  The two tanks will be administratively controlled such that their aggregate capacity will not exceed 80,000 gallons.  The total quantity of ammonia exceeds threshold quantities which invoke the requirements of the Risk Management regulations.

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

CSS has conducted an offsite consequence analysis as required by regulations, including an extremely unlikely, worst-case release scenario (i.e., total release of one of the tanks assuming worst case meteorological conditions).  Results of this worst-case event indicate that offsite receptors could be affected.

A release represented by this worst-case is extremely unlikely because of the design of the system components and the prevention program that has been put in place.

EPA chemical release reporting databases, EPA guidance documents, and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulations is so unlikely that it should not be used as a basis for emergency planning purposes.  A more realistic potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented below.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There is no specific accident history for the ammonia system as this is a new installation.

CSS has previously and will continue to handle ammonia in a smaller capacity system (below EPA threshold quantity) for flue gas conditioning.  The accident history for this existing use was reviewed for comparative purposes.  Within the past five years, CSS has had no accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage.  The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had any major chemical release that could have had adverse effects on the public.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

In the event that an ammonia release does occur, CSS has an emergency response program that coordinates emergency response with the appropriate off-site agencies including the Rutherford and Cleveland County Emergency Planning and Management agencies and the Cliffside Fire Department.  CSS maintains a 24/7 emergency response team on-site with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action necessary to secure credible releases of ammonia that might occur.  Additionally, there are a number of emergency operations procedures in place which detail the appropriate emergency actions that would help mitigate the effects of releases.

MAINTAINING A SAFE OPERATION

Duke Energy and Cliffside Steam Station will continually work to safely manage the hazards of the ammonia system to protect the communities we serve and the employees, vendors and visitors at the station.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to re

duce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices.  Periodically, CSS will audit the program, review the Process Hazard Analysis, coordinate wth community emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the anhydrous ammonia system.
